abstract.p: Dudley C Smith letter warmly recalls conversation with veteran New York City cab driver Sam Goldstein, who thanked Smith's wife for her work as a nurse helping displaced people like himself after World War II

block.p: Your Dec. 7 front-page article about Sam Goldstein, a taxi driver (''46 Years in Cab, Recalling That Tip From Marilyn''), brought back a warming memory.
Your Dec. 7 front-page article about Sam Goldstein, a taxi driver (''46 Years in Cab, Recalling That Tip From Marilyn''), brought back a warming memory.
Two years ago almost to the day, blustery and cold in early evening, this same Sam Goldstein drove us from J.F.K. to our Manhattan place on 52nd Street.

During the ride, Sam and my wife shared stories of postwar Germany. In 1947, he was a youth housed in the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration camp in Zeilsheim, Germany, where she served as a Belgian nurse for U.N.R.R.A., caring for displaced persons. It is all but certain that they must have met then and there.

Sam did not just drop us off when we arrived. Braving wind and snow and snarling traffic, he walked to the curb where she was standing, embraced her suddenly and said, ''Thank you for saving my life.''
It was a beautiful moment that Liliane and I remember vividly.
DUDLEY C. SMITH New York, Dec. 7, 2003
